Message.Title: OPEC Says Supply Ample, Speculation Driving Price
Message.Msg: OPEC Says Supply Ample, Speculation Driving Price , | 03 June 2013 | 06:18 AM ET Oil supply will be more than sufficient to meet demand this year and beyond, OPEC's Secretary General said on Thursday, but added the price of fuel is being driven higher by speculation. "There has been no shortage of oil in the market. Producers have been able to meet consumer needs," Abdullah al-Badri told an energy conference. "We also see this as being the case for the rest of 2012 and the foreseeable future." Oil prices surged in March to $128 a barrel, the highest level since 2008, because of concern about possible supply shortages. Prices have since fallen back and brent crude was trading around $118 on Thursday. "Today the price continues to be driven by excessive speculation," Badri said. OPEC at a meeting in December set a target to produce 30 million barrels per day, settling an argument which broke out in 2011 after Iran and other members opposed a Saudi-led plan to raise OPEC's production ceiling. Output has remained above the target all year as Libyan supply recovered after being virtually shut down during the 2011 uprising against Muammar Gaddafi's rule. The extra oil is filling gaps caused by an unusually large number of supply outages globally, which have also helped support prices. Supply breaks were running at nearly 1.3 million bpd as of early April. The additional supply has also offset a decline in exports from Iran, which is facing stiffening western sanctions over its disputed nuclear energy program. Iranian oil exports were running at between 200,000 and 300,000 barrels per day below last year's level, Maria van der Hoeven, head of the International Energy Agency, told Thursday's conference. Iranian officials have said the country exported an average of 2.2 million barrels a day last year. July supply from the 12-member Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries ran at 31.75 million barrels per day (bpd), the high est since September 2008, which was

Message.Title: Nuverra Environmental Solutions (NYSE: NES )
Message.Msg: Next up is Nuverra Environmental Solutions (NYSE: NES ) , formerly known as Heckmann, a full-service provider of water management solutions. Over the next several years, the company stands to benefit from one major trend: the scarcity of water for fracking operations and the need to efficiently recycle and reuse it. What sets Nuverra apart from some of its competitors, such as Key Energy (NYSE: KEG ) -- a fluid-treatment provider that focuses mainly on water disposal -- is its overarching focus on treating and recycling produced water, as opposed to just disposing it.

Message.Msg: Research Concurrent (CCUR) they reported that their GAAP EPS last quarter was up 175% year-over-year and they just raised their dividend by 100% to $0.48 for a yield here at $8 of 6%! CCUR has trailing free cash flow of $5.6 million or $0.64 per share. CCUR's rival Seachange (SEAC) is now trading for $11.54 or 28.15X its free cash flow of $0.41 per share. Last week at the Cable Show in Washington DC, Comcast announced they will be launching their own cloud based Network DVR technology later this year. Topic.Title: BAC--Schizophrenic Investing

Message.Msg: If it is proven in court that the allegations against BAC are true that they continue to abuse the foreclosure, then 1) they should be made to pay to the fullest extent the law allows and 2) I will have no problem selling all my shares as a matter of principle. There comes a point where certain ethical lines are crossed. I do not believe in investing with my eyes closed. For instance, I do not invest in companies involved in the production of alcoholic, tobacco, or firearm products. I don't have any issue adding BAC, or any other bank that abuses their position of power, to that list.

Message.Title: Is BAC's culture is one of criminal behavior - why non-stop headlines they did wrong
Message.Msg: First they settle but then give bonuses to employees to flount the agreements - if not criminal, that's unethical. BAC has had more headlines than any other bank about their employees' criminal behavior. It's a case of culture and Moynihan has not been willing or is unable to change. This non-stop lawsuits about BAC doing something wrong is so distracting and annoying to investors. Why can't they get their act together. They should fire some people who are bad fish or replace Moynihan - BAC needs to have a clean image or else who wants to open an account with them if they are perceived as an unethical company.

Message.Title: Shocked
Message.Msg: Six former Bank of America Corp employees have alleged that the bank deliberately denied eligible home owners loan modifications and lied to them about the status of their mortgage payments and documents. The bank allegedly used these tactics to shepherd homeowners into foreclosure, as well as in-house loan modifications. Both yielded the bank more profits than the government-sponsored Home Affordable Modification Program, according to documents recently filed as part of a lawsuit in Massachusetts federal court.
